<s>Proceedings <\s> Archives 91.2 76 17
On the Alimentary Canal of Pontia brassicae.
By
A.B. Griffiths, Ph.D., F.R.S. (Edin.), F.C.S., &c.
Communicated by T.H. Huxley F.R.S.
Received April 1. 1892 Read June 16 1892
In continuing his researches on the physiology of 
the <u>Invertebrata <\u>, the author gives the following 
account of the alimentary canal of the larva and 
imago of <u>Pontia brassicae <\u>>, which has not been in-
vestigated by other workers.
The alimentary canal of the larva (Fig.1) begins with 
an oral aperture which opens into a pharynx lined 
by a dark, firm cuticula. Behind the oral aperture 
is a projecting process, at the tip of which opens the 
salivary duct. There are a pair of these ducts which 
proceed from two well-developed salivary glands.
These glands form elongated tubes, gradually dimin-
ishing in diameter towards the posterior ends. The 
oesophagus is very narrow and short. It leads
into a long stomach, which opens into a short duct.
